text: the Long Island Railroad is a commuter
train system that transports millions of
people a month between New York City and
the Long Island suburbs despite the fact
that the railroad has won national
awards for employee safety in recent
years a New York Times investigation has
discovered an epidemic of Occupational
disabilities in the workforce
virtually every career employee who
retires from the railroad as many as 97
percent in one year applies for and gets
a monthly disability check according to
analysis of federal records former Long
Island Railroad employees have collected
nearly a quarter of a billion dollars in
disability payments since 2000 and it's
not just engineers conductors and other
blue-collar workers white-collar
managers are doing it as well The Times
presented these findings to Halina
Williams president of the LIRR
they leave Long Island Railroad from our
perspective a healthy person going out
to enjoy their retirement and within a
short period of time they are able to
qualify for an occupational disability
suggesting that they're no longer
capable of performing in the railroad
industry the Long Island Railroad has a
unique situation unlike many other
railroads nationwide the Lyell railroad
has a closed pension plan that allows
employees to reach full retirement at
age 50 soon after retiring most
employees file for occupational
disability here in Chicago the Federal
Railroad Retirement Board rules on
railroad disability claims and partly
due to provisions in the law almost
everyone is approved well I think the
acceptance rate is 98 percent so the
rejection rate obviously 2% know most
non-existent
with their pension and an average
disability payment of $3,000 a month
some retired LIRR employees in their 50s
can earn roughly the base salary of
their old jobs without having to work
while some of the retirees undoubtedly
have legitimate disabilities the sheer
numbers raise questions about whether
hundreds of others are abusing the
system the times compared the
disabilities claimed by retired LIRR
workers to those claimed by workers at
Metro North another New York City
commuter rail with a workforce of
similar size and composition
from 2001 through 2007 under the disease
category arthritis and rheumatism there
were 750 three cases of retired LIRR
workers claiming this disability and
only 32 for metro-north for certain
diseases of the musculoskeletal system
there were eight hundred and fifty Li
our workers claiming this disability and
only 49 from Metro North we asked the
Railroad Retirement Board about our
findings how does one account for such
wide disparities I don't know yeah I
don't think we I don't think we know
that Railroad Retirement officials say
that the burden of proof for
occupational disability is set by
Congress what we try and do is
administer the law as best we can the
way it's been written under the federal
rules retirees can legally claim
disability for jobs after they retire
and those disabilities don't have to be
work-related
in fact if the LIRR white-collar
managers have been taking advantage as
well like the LIRR s deputy general
counsel the employment manager and the
director of government and Community
Affairs all claimed occupational
disability after they retired theaters
an engineer or be it as a manager at a
desk you can qualify in reality you just
have a perfect storm which may be
creating this drain on on the coffers of
the pension fund during the week it's
not uncommon to find dozens of Long
Island Railroad retirees with
occupational disabilities here at Long
Island sunken meadow Golf Course as
disabled workers they golf for free
courtesy of New York State taxpayers
Joe Rutigliano is a retired Long Island
Railroad conductor and former union
official rare returned what provides
enough criteria
if you have the physical impairments
that they say can't perform your errand
occupation you get one of them
particularly on Oh says he crushed his
back in an accident at home on the
railroad conductor okay I climbed up and
down engines fell couples cause I
climbed ballast I worked it worked the
trains I didn't need to use my legs my
back every day and since 1988 I worked
with a bad back he retired with a
regular pension over a decade later at
age 52 and like hundreds of other former
long island railroad workers applied for
occupational disability law provides is
what the doctors the doctors know why
they got x-rays MRIs they have bad backs
AB hearing disabilities and they
complain and under the law they got an
occupational disability losing so many
workers to occupational disability cost
the Long Island Railroad money in
overtime training replacements and early
pension payments all at a time when
passengers faced yet another fare
increase and the railroads parent the
Metropolitan Transportation Authority is
seeking more taxpayer support already
half a billion dollars a year to cover a
huge budget gap but if you've managed to
work for 30 years get to full retirement
at age 50 and have this opportunity that
appears to be open and available to you
by railroad retirement to document you
know maybe what is just plain old wear
and tear on your body I mean let's face
it if railroad retirement is accepting
that as a disability then then we have
to question what is railroad retirement
standard after the times presented its
findings to Helena Williams she sent a
letter to the Railroad Retirement Board
in Chicago asking why so many Long
Island Railroad retirees were claiming
disability some people may say whether
abusing the system but like I said
before that is what the statute says
and that is the system and if Congress
wants to change the statute and raise
the threshold that's up to Congress
that's not up to us to do
you
